results.title: Rainforest
results.creator_credit: David Oppenheim and National Educational Television
results.brief_description: First performance by Merce Cunningham and Dance Company at the 2nd Buffalo Festival of the Arts, March 9, 1968 of “Rainforest”, a contemporary, non-expressive dance, with sets by Andy Warhol, costumes by Jasper Johns, choreography by Merce Cunningham and music by David Tudor. Dancers include Merce Cunningham, Barbara Lloyd, Albert Reid, Carolyn Brown, Sandra Neels, Gus Solomons.

results.title: Rainbow war (K)
results.brief_description: A spectacular film using a combination of many animation forms as well as live-action. Three imaginary kingdoms, a blue, red and yellow kingdom, meet and fight a battle for colour supremacy. Finally, amazed by the variety of colours and beauty that had been created, the three kingdoms agreed to coexist in peace.

results.title: Rainbow reel
results.brief_description: A collection of animated shorts made by children. Titles include: The Blob”, “The Drag”, “Stanley the pink unicorn”, “That’s progress and “Patterns” which includes music by Simon and Garfunkle.

results.title: Rainbow dance
results.creator_credit: Len Lye and GPO Film Unit
results.brief_description: An early experimental film using flat colour silhouettes of dancing figures, based on live photography. Made as a Post Office Savings Bank publicity film, Rainbow Dance’s original technique of colour reproduction, together with the later films “Kaleidoscope” and “Tusalava” foreshadowed some of Norman McLaren’s work.

results.title: Rain from the Danube
results.creator_credit: Peter Bradford, Sahia Films Bucharest and World Wide Pictures
results.brief_description: A film showing how the skills of British engineers and equipment were employed in the irrigation of the Danube Basin in Romania; an area of 300 square miles.

results.title: Railways of Australia
results.creator_credit: William M. Carty, Frank Killian, Cinesound Movietone and Commonwealth Railways
results.brief_description: Surveys the railway system in Australia today, and the need for its maintenance and improvement to meet the ever-increasing calls for all forms of quick and efficient transportation. Stresses the importance of railways for carrying large numbers of people and raw materials.
results.creator_credit_for_label: William M. Carty, Frank Killian, Cinesound Movietone and Commonwealth Railways

results.title: Railways for ever
results.creator_credit: Norman Prouting and British Transport Films
results.brief_description: The last steam train crossing the Pennines and an Edwardian concert hall song “Watching the trains go out”, bring back many memories to Sir John Betjeman. In his own nostalgic verse and prose, he remembers the great trains of old and looks forward to railways for ever as he moves through a photographic exhibition.

results.title: Railway worker
results.brief_description: Brief scenes of railway workers in New Zealand at work in the many essential jobs of the system, with impressions of life in isolated railway communities.

results.title: Railway Centenary Exhibition
results.creator_credit: Jagat Murari, M. Bhavnani and Documentary Films of India
results.brief_description: The Rialway Centenary Exhibition was organised in Delhi as a fitting memorial to the saga of Indian railways. Glimpses of the manifold achievements of Indian railways, including the Chittaranjan Locomotive Workshops, the Integral Coach Factory near Madras and TELCO at Jamshedpur.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jagat Murari, M. Bhavnani and Documentary Films of India
